indicators.justification:
Emissions information for Malta is available through its National Inventory Submissions as an Annex I party (1). The data reported contains information on greenhouse gas emissions and targets reported to the UNFCCC. It also contains information on the total GHG emissions by sector and by gas. Details also include land use effects on emissions (1).

1)	United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, National Inventory Submissions 2021, 2021. https://unfccc.int/ghg-inventories-annex-i-parties/2021.

indicators.justification:
Data for Malta with regard to beneficial ownership information is available through the Malta Business Registry (MBR) (1). The data contains unique identifiers for entries such as the official company registration number which is a unique number. Public users can request details on beneficial owners. The data provided includes the full name, date of birth, nationality, and country of residence of the beneificial owners of a company (2). Requests for information through the MBR are not free of charge and no tools exist to help users explore the data available. The data is also not entirely up-to-date with the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) requesting Malta to rectify this situation (3).

1)	Malta Business Registry, n.d., Search for Beneficial Owners. https://registry.mbr.mt/ROC/index.jsp#involvementSearch.do?involvement=UBO.
2)	Malta Business Registry, n.d., Guidance on the Register of Beneficial Owners of Commercial Partnerships. https://mbr.mt/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/Guidance-document-on-the-Register-of-Beneficial-Owners-of-Commercial-Partnerships.pdf.
3)	The Malta Independent, 2021, FATF highlights the three action points Malta needs to fulfill to move off grey list. https://www.independent.com.mt/articles/2021-06-25/local-news/FATF-highlights-the-three-action-points-Malta-needs-to-fulfill-to-move-off-grey-list-6736234688

indicators.justification:
Searches for company information in Malta can be done via the Malta Business Registry (MBR) (1). A public user is able to search for a company using its name or registration number. The user is granted information on the regisration number, the company name, its registration date, the address of its registered office, the locality, and country. A user is also given information on the authorised shares, involved parties, beneficial owners, and other documents. A user is only able to download a document after making the necessary payments. The data is available in English, one of Malta's two official languages. Information is not provided as a whole and a user must make individual searches for company information.

1)	Malta Business Registry, n.d., Company Search. https://registry.mbr.mt/ROC/index.jsp#companySearch.do?action=companyDetails.

indicators.justification:
Civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) information is available as open data to a very limited extent. The data available is far from the scope envisioned by this indicator and is mainly limited to annual reports presenting monthly or annual tallies (1) (2). Even when taking into consideration the annual reports, the data presented is not available at such a granular level as envisioned by the indicator (e.g. place occurance of birth, place of usual residence of mother, and month of occurance). While not an adequate justification for the lack of most data, one may wish to keep in mind the relatively small size of Malta meaning that it may be easier for a person to be identified from public data which could interfere with patient confidentiality rights (3).

1)	Ministry for Health, Births, n.d.. https://deputyprimeminister.gov.mt/en/dhir/Pages/Registries/births.aspx.
2)	Ministry for Health, Deaths, n.d.. https://deputyprimeminister.gov.mt/en/dhir/Pages/Registries/deaths.aspx.
3)	Ministry for Health, Patient's Charter, n.d.. https://deputyprimeminister.gov.mt/en/hcs/Pages/patients-charter.aspx.

indicators.justification:
Land use information for Malta is available through the Planning Authority's servers (1).	The available Geoserver provides users with key information on Malta's terrain – buildings, open space, and roads. It is composed of 18 layers and contains over 50 classifications (2). In terms of forested areas, the Geoserver does not specifically classify and mark these regions. However, it includes information on areas marked for environmental protection and other similar designations. Precise coordinates are provided for any point selected. The available data is free to access, however the amount and variety of data available is limited (e.g. no data on forested areas).
1)	Planning Authority, Geoserver, n.d..  http://geoserver.pa.org.mt/publicgeoserver
2)	Planning Authority, Geoserver help, n.d.. https://www.pa.org.mt/geoserverhelp

indicators.justification:
A request for data can be made from the government's website, specifically at the Land Registry (1). However, the data is not open. The data is also not available on demand. An application must be submitted (two days), it is then vetted (one) day, the application is then assessed (two days), then the service is delivered (two). Furthermore, a notary is required to perform such a search. Therefore an online user who is not a notary can not access this data (2).

1) Land Registration Agency,Land Registration Agency n.d.. https://landregistry.gov.mt/mt/Pages/default.aspx.
2) Government of Malta, Request for an Official Search and/or Information for Property, n.d.. https://www.servizz.gov.mt/en/Pages/Environment_-Energy_-Agriculture-and-Fisheries/Environment/Building-Planning/WEB064/default.aspx

evidence.title: Request for an Official Search and/or Information for Property (Form E)

indicators.justification:
Every year the Maltese government presents it's annual budget in parliament. Information is also published online. This would include the budget speech, the financial estimates, the economic survey, and the pre-budget document (1). The data is only available once and is not updated on an accrual basis in structured data formats. The same applies for extrabudgetary funds, social security spending, and public corporation spending. Financial transactions are not available at the most disaggregated levels.
1)	Ministry for Finance, The Budget 2021, 2021, https://finance.gov.mt/en/The-Budget/Pages/The-Budget-2021-ND111213.aspx.

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.

The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

indicators.justification:
Every year, Government MPs usually submit declaration of assets that are tabled in parliament. The latest declaration of assets available is that for the year 2020 (1). The data typically contains information on income, assets, and liabilities for Government MPs however the level of detail varies as a non-standardised form is filled in and scanned. This submission procedure and non-adherence to guidelines leads to varying results. Sometimes data can even be missing, as is the case for Prime Minister Robert Abela who failed to list his income in the asset declarations (2). Information does not typically contain information about assets of family members (3).
1)	Parliament of Malta, n.d., Paper Laid No.: 6790. https://www.parlament.mt/en/paper-laid/?id=34728&page=1&criteria=declaration&itemsPerPage=10.
2)	Borg Jacob, Times of Malta, Robert Abela fails to list income in asset filings, 2021. https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/pm-fails-to-list-income-in-asset-filings.880211.
3)	Martin Ivan and Xuereb Matthew, Times of Malta, 2020, MPs refuse to divulge families' assets. https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/mps-refuse-to-divulge-families-assets.831823.

evidence.title: Robert Abela fails to list income in asset filings
Code of Ethics for Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries

indicators.justification:
The Commissioner for Standards in Public Life is appointed by the President of Malta and has jurisdiction over MPs and persons of trust. The Commissioner can consider whether or not MPs are in breach of ethics rules among other duties (1). There are currently no specific rules on lobbying activities, however, following comparative research on how lobbying is regulated in several jurisdictions, the Commissioner for Standards in Public Life has formulated proposals for lobbying in Malta to be governed by law. The aim is to increase transparency and improve standards of governance in Malta (2). The draft proposals are still in consultation phase.Therefore, no such data is available.
1)	Office of the Commissioner for Standards in Public Life, n.d., The role of the Standards Commissioner. https://standardscommissioner.com/the-role-of-the-commissioner/.
2)	Office of the Commissioner for Standards in Public Life, 2020, Towards the Regulation of Lobbying in Malta. https://standardscommissioner.com/wp-content/uploads/consultation-paper-lobbying.pdf.

evidence.title: he role of the Standards Commissioner
Towards the Regulation of Lobbying in Malta

indicators.justification:
Information on political finance information is available through the website of the Maltese Electoral Commission (1). The latest submissions available are for 2019 and concen only one minor political party – the two main political parties' submissions for 2019 do not feature on the website. The last available statement of accounts for the two main parties are dated 2018 (2). The submitted documents come in the form of PDFs and contain basic data on income, expenditure, assets, and liabilities of the political parties. The submitted accounts do not typically include details of non-financial support, timing and amount of donations, information on each donor, etc. 
1)	Electoral Commission Malta, FINANCING OF POLITICAL PARTIES – 2019, 2019. https://electoral.gov.mt/finance-en
2)	Electoral Commission Malta, FINANCING OF POLITICAL PARTIES – 2018, 2018. https://electoral.gov.mt/finance2018-en.

indicators.justification:
Malta's Freedom of Information (FOI) Act deals with the guidance for collecting and publishing data on the performace on Malta's FOI processes. The FOI Act charges the relevant commissioner with submitting an annual report to the relevant minister who in turn should table it in the Maltese parliament at the first available opportunity. The FOI Act demands that the report in question should state the number of FOI requests made, how many of them were accepted or rejected, the reasons for rejection, the average time taken to reply to requests, the number of complaints received (and other related information), the number of appeals lodged with the relevant tribunal, the number of various notices issued by the commissioner (1). Although the law stipulates an annual report detailing FOI requests, rejections, and otherwise, the last available report is dated 2018 and it does not include all the information required (2). This means that the current data available falls out of the time period relevant for the barometer.
1)	Freedom of Information Act, Cap. 496, Art. 21. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/496/eng/pdf
2)	Information and Data Protection Commissioner, 2018, Annual Report 2018. https://parlament.mt/media/105028/04560.pdf.

indicators.justification:
Citing the spirit of openness and transparency, the Government of Malta hosts an online public consultations platform (1). Its aim is to encourage the general public, civil society organisations, trade unions, business organisations, and others to contribute to and participate in the processes of online public consultations (2). A number of data items can be found including information on the creator of the public consultation, information about the project to be consulted about, and further information on submissions received etc. 
1)	Ministry For European Affairs And Equality, n.d., Public Consultation.gov.mt. https://meae.gov.mt/en/Pages/PublicConsultations.aspx
2)	Ministry For European Affairs And Equality, n.d., Public Consultations Online. https://meae.gov.mt/en/Public_Consultations/Pages/Home.aspx.

indicators.justification:
Public procurement data in Malta is available through the etenders government website (1). The e-PPS is a web-based system to facilitate the full lifecycle of a tendering process (1). Procurement of any nature is covered (eg. services, public works, etc.) (1). Economic Operators must register on the website and provide mandatory information that includes the organisation name, organisation type, organisation size, company registration number or VAT number or business identification number, country, address, postal code, city, email, phone number, and fax (optional) (2). While access to the service is free for public users, a user may not use any API or ather automated method to access or copy or use any portion of the website and its services (3). It is to be clarified that the information available is that of a data portal and not a dataset. Data is often in PDF format, i.e. not machine-readable.
1)	Government of Malta, n.d., etenders.gov.mt. https://www.etenders.gov.mt/epps/home.do.
2)	European Dynamics S.A., n.d., Public Procurement Service Economic Operators User Manual. https://www.etenders.gov.mt/epps/cft/downloadInfoItem.do?documentId=7328456.
3)	Etenders.gov.mt, 2018, General Terms of Use. https://www.etenders.gov.mt/epps/docs/eTenders_Terms_of_Use.pdf.

indicators.justification:
No evidence was found that the government of Malta is providing support for data reuse. Malta remains a beginner in terms of open data (1). This means that the level of open data to begin with is already limited which could explain why no support can be given in this area with the current status quo.
1)	European Data Portal, Open Data Maturity, 2020. https://data.europa.eu/sites/default/files/edp_landscaping_insight_report_n6_2020.pdf.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.

Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

indicators.justification:
The open government data initiative in Malta leaves much to be desired. Despite being lauched in 2014,  Malta is still classified as a beginner in open data (1). The amount of open data is also very limited. The contents of the portal are still a work in progress and can not be considered to be official records (2).
1)	Azzopardi Joseph, 2021, Online Interview, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ozA2x2L94Y8.
2)	Malta Data Portal, Disclaimer, n.d.. https://open.data.gov.mt/dashboard.html.

Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

responses.response_text: The open data initiatives covers much of both national and sub-national government.

indicators.justification:
The national government of Malta has a sub-par capability and/or willingness to effectively manage data. The situation for city, regional, and local governments is even bleaker with no evidence of any sort of movement in this area. Malta remains a beginner in terms of open data (1). It is rare to find local government initiatives in areas which are not actively supported by the national government.

1)	European Data Portal, Open Data Maturity, 2020. https://data.europa.eu/sites/default/files/edp_landscaping_insight_report_n6_2020.pdf

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.

There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: No cities or regions show capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
Some evidence of Malta government training initiatives for civil servants emerges through its Institute for the Public Services (IPS) (1). The type of education and training ranges from EU funding to public procurement to working remotely (2). The training and education is not necessarily available to all user groups. Courses usually have target groups and a public servant's application may be rejected if they fall outside this group. Although individuals can apply on their own initiative, they may require approval form their line manager. Alternatively they could be nominated by their line manager for specific training (3). The IPS covers all government sectors nationwide.
1)	Government of Malta, n.d., Institute for the Public Services. https://publicservice.gov.mt/en/institute/Pages/Home.aspx.
2)	Insitute for the Public Services, 2021, Prospectus 2021-2022. https://publicservice.gov.mt/en/institute/Documents/IPS%20Prospectus%20Leaflet%202021%202022.pdf.
3)	Institute for the Public Services, 2021, FAQs Training. https://publicservice.gov.mt/en/institute/Pages/Support/Training_FAQs.aspx.

responses.response_text: There is some evidence of government  supporting civil servants training on data matters, as part of a planned and sustainable strategy.

Training delivered covers data frameworks and governance topics.
Training delivered to public servants covers topics on data gathering.
Training delivered covers data analysis, visualisations and storytelling techniques.
Training delivered covers specific technical topics for data centred roles.
Training on data addresses non-technical public servants.
Training on data is focused on specific positions already working with data.
Training is planned by an established training team, department, or agency.
Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

indicators.justification: No one single system exists that offers political integrity data interoperable across different political integrity datasets, as well as other datasets associated with relevant information flows. Some identifiers may overlap in different indicators when there is a fixed 'national unified identifier' such as the national ID card number of an individual.

responses.response_text: The datasets use a limited number of common identifiers.

Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

responses.response_text: There is minimal consistency; at least one category of identifiers is consistent across two datasets.

indicators.justification:
Malta transposed both the 4th and 5th AMLD directives into local law. The legal amendments pertaining to the latter entered into force with effect from 1 January 2020. Nevertheless, Malta repeatedly missed implementation deadlines, particularly with regard to the 4th and 5th AMLD directives (1) (2). Malta's Prevention of Money Laundering and Funding of Terrorism Regulations define "beneficial owner" and incorporates the necessary framework to deal with this issue (3). Elements from AMLD4 and AMLD5 were transposed locally via Legal Notice 373 of 2017 and Legal Notice 27 of 2020 (4). 

1)	Borg Jacob, Times of Malta, Malta misses deadline on money laundering,2017. https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/malta-misses-deadline-on-money-laundering.652000
2)	Farrugia Claire, Times of Malta, Commission awaits data on anti-money laundering law, 2020. https://timesofmalta.com/articles/view/commission-awaits-data-on-anti-money-laundering-law.764238?fbclid=IwAR08XY5GjSNCIXRIfjF9R3PEGneJ9m7VVEWYVDDlUm05eQ5OtTFfFKO4CKI.
3)	SUBSIDIARY LEGISLATION 373.01 PREVENTION OF MONEY LAUNDERING AND FUNDING OF TERRORISM REGULATIONS, 2018, LN 372 of 2017, SL 373.01. https://www.legislationline.org/download/id/7937/file/Malta_prevention_money_laundering_financing_terrorism_regulations_2018_en.pdf.
4) Camilleri Petra, MFSA, Transposition of the 5th AML Directive, 2020. https://www.mfsa.mt/publication/transposition-of-the-5th-aml-directive/.

indicators.justification:
While not specifically mentioned in the original act, the re-use of information act implements the provisions of Directive (EU) 2019/1024 which in itself refers to accessibility requirements for people with disabilities (1).

In addition to accessibility rights for people with disabilities, Malta's EQUAL OPPORTUNITIES (PERSONS WITH DISABILITY) ACT, Cap. 413, 2000 Art 3(6) envisions accessible information in a format of one's choice (2).

1) RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT, Cap. 546, Art 1 (2), 2015. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/546/eng/pdf.

2) EQUAL OPPORTUNITIES (PERSONS WITH DISABILITY) ACT, Cap. 413, 2000 Art 3(6). https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/413/eng/pdf.

indicators.justification:
The draft strategy 'Data-Driven Public Administration National Data Strategy' is still in draft stage which could provide Malta with a more detailed framework in this regard (1). However, until it is finalised, the The RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT (2) covers the requirements for this indicator.

1) MITA, Data-Driven Public Administration National Data Strategy, 2016. https://mita.gov.mt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Data-Driven-Public-Administration-Malta.pdf.

2) RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT , Cap. 546, 2015. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/546/eng/pdf.

indicators.justification:
Malta's Re-Use of Public Sector Information Act provides a framework for information sharing (1). While it covers sharing governmental data interally and externally, it doesn't specify a framework for sharing to occur from outside towards the government nor sharing within the private sector. Nevertheless, the framework applies to all governmental agencies.

1) RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT, Cap. 546, 2015. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/546/eng/pdf.

evidence.title: CHAPTER 546 RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.

The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed covers all government agencies, and many themes.

indicators.justification:
Malta's main law concerning a framework for the protection of personal data comes via the Data Protection Act (1). In addition to the safeguards that it provides, it also implements the EU's GDPR regulation (2). In today's modern world where data is being digitalised, the Processing of Personal Data (Electronic Communications Sector) Regulations also cover specific instances of consent, rights to access, and other such scenarios (3). The regulator overseeing data protection in Malta is the Office of the Information and Data Protection Commissioner (IDPC) that tackles wide ranging issues from personal data breaches to assisting with the application of GDPR (4).

1) DATA PROTECTION ACT, Cap. 586, 2018. https://idpc.org.mt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/CAP-586.pdf
2) DATA PROTECTION ACT, Cap. 586, Art2, 2018. https://idpc.org.mt/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/CAP-586.pdf
3) PROCESSING OF PERSONAL DATA (ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS SECTOR) REGULATIONS, SL 586.01, 2003. https://legislation.mt/eli/sl/586.1/eng.
4) IDPC, n.d., Our Office, https://idpc.org.mt/our-office/.

evidence.title: PROCESSING OF PERSONAL DATA (ELECTRONIC COMMUNICATIONS SECTOR) REGULATIONS, SL 586.01, 2003
PROCESSING OF PERSONAL DATA (SECONDARY PROCESSING) (HEALTH SECTOR) REGULATIONS, S.L. 528.10, 2019.

The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.

The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed, or equivalent frameworks, apply across the whole country.

indicators.justification:
There is no specific framework in terms of laws, regulations, policies, and guidance require that data collection and publication processes be available in the country's official or national languages. However, documents/notifications/announcements in Malta are frequently published in either English or Maltese or both. Notwithstanding, Maltese and English remain the two official languages of Malta. Maltese remains the sole national language (1).

1) CONSTITUTION OF MALTA, Art 5. https://www.parlament.mt/media/82078/constitution.pdf.

indicators.justification:
Malta's Re-Use of Public Sector Information Act provides a framework for generating and publishing information and public documents (1). The act establishes various definitions including those for open format, machine readability, and the re-use of documents (2). This act also covers the whole country.
1) RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT, Cap. 546, 2020. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/546/20200327/eng.
2) RE-USE OF PUBLIC SECTOR INFORMATION ACT, Cap. 546, Art.2, 2020. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/546/20200327/eng.

indicators.justification:
In Malta, the National Statistics Office (NSO) is responsible for disseminating official statistics about various matters (1). Such published knowledge includes information on the expenditure of the general government by sector and function (COFOG) (2). The laws discuss the dissemination of data but do not specify the dissemination of open data. In terms of the executive budget, the corresponding rules applicable are those concerning the financial estimates in terms of the Maltese constitution (3) and Financial Administration and Audit Act (4).

1)	MALTA STATISTICS AUTHORITY ACT, Cap. 422, Art 7, 01/03/2001. https://nso.gov.mt/Home/ABOUT_NSO/Documents/Legislation/MaltaStatisticsAuthorityAct.pdf
2)	Expenditure of General Government Sector by Function, NSO, n.d. https://nso.gov.mt/en/nso/Sources_and_Methods/Unit_A2/Public_Finance/Pages/Expenditure-of-General-Government-Sector-by-Function.aspx.
3)	Constitution of Malta, Art. 102-108. https://legislation.mt/eli/const/eng/pdf.
4)	FINANCIAL ADMINISTRATION AND AUDIT ACT, Cap. 174, Art. 22-25, 29/05/1962. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/174/eng/pdf.

indicators.justification:
Malta does have policies regarding the publishing of data on the interests and assets of some public officials, namely a code of ethics for Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries (1). Said code of ethics obliges Ministers to declare any assets and interests to the Cabinet Secretary. Interest that may give rise to the perception of conflict of interest, aside fomr actual conflict of interest, should also be indicated. Such a statement is to be provided annualy.

1)	Code of Ethics for Ministers and Parliamentary Secretaries, n.d. https://standardscommissioner.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Code-of-Ethics-Ministers.pdf.

evidence.title: MPs refuse to divulge families’ assets

indicators.justification:
The Commissioner for Standards in Public Life is appointed by the President of Malta and has jurisdiction over MPs and persons of trust. The Commissioner can consider whether or not MPs are in breach of ethics rules among other duties (1). There are currently no specific rules on lobbying activities, however, following comparative research on how lobbying is regulated in several jurisdictions, the Commissioner for Standards in Public Life has formulated proposals for lobbying in Malta to be governed by law. The aim is to increase transparency and improve standards of governance in Malta (2). The draft proposals are still in consultation phase.
1)	Office of the Commissioner for Standards in Public Life, n.d., The role of the Standards Commissioner. https://standardscommissioner.com/the-role-of-the-commissioner/.
2)	Office of the Commissioner for Standards in Public Life, 2020, Towards the Regulation of Lobbying in Malta. https://standardscommissioner.com/wp-content/uploads/consultation-paper-lobbying.pdf.

evidence.title: Ministers should not lobby after holding office - Standards Commissioner
Towards the Regulation of Lobbying in Malta

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

The framework contains clear and unambiguous definitions of lobbyists, lobbying clients, lobbying activities, and public officials.
The framework requires the collection and publication of the identities of lobbyists, lobbyist clients, and public officials who engage with lobbyists.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on lobbyists' goals for lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on timing of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on topics of lobbying activities.
The framework requires the collection and publication of information on how much money is spent on lobbying activities.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

indicators.justification:
Prior to the enactment of the Financing of Political Parties Act (FPPA) political parties were not subject to accounting and disclosure rules (1). The bill was approved in July 2015 and is still in place clearly defining political parties and donations pertaining to them (1). The FPPA tasks the Maltese Electoral Commission with going through the accounts of the various political parties (2). The same act requires parties to keep standard accounting records including records of assets and liabilities (3). While on paper the framework may appear robust, it faces frequent criticism due to lack of enforcement and transparency (4).
1)	Muscat Brandon, n.d., Curing the Cancer of Corruption: A comparitive and analytical study of the Political Parties Financing Act. https://avukatmuscat.com/index.php/download/financing-of-political-parties/.
2)	FINANCING OF POLITICAL PARTIES ACT, Cap. 544, Art 22, 2015. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/544/eng/pdf.
3)	FINANCING OF POLITICAL PARTIES ACT, Cap. 544, Art 23, 2015. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/544/eng/pdf.
4)	Peregin Chris, 2021, It's Official: Malta's Party Financing Law Is Broken And Our Electoral Watchdog Won't Probe Breaches Until It's Fixed. https://lovinmalta.com/news/its-official-maltas-party-financing-law-is-broken-and-our-electoral-watchdog-wont-probe-breaches-until-its-fixed/

evidence.title: It’s Official: Malta’s Party Financing Law Is Broken And Our Electoral Watchdog Won’t Probe Breaches Until It’s Fixed

indicators.justification:
Directive 6 issued by the Principal Permanent Secretary in line with the Public Administration Act concerns the consultation with stakeholders. Among other things, Directive 6 recognises that consultation is an inherent means of ensuring stakeholder involvement in decision making stating that in the past years a number of positive consultation exercises were carried out (1). While the directive's spirit encourages consultation, it does not set out specific and binding measures about how this should be done (e.g. notices of intent, reasoned responses, etc.).
1)	Office of the Principal Permanent Secretary, 2011, Directive No. 6. https://publicservice.gov.mt/en/people/Documents/Directives/Directive-6.pdf.

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: There is no mention of data or the publication of data in relevant laws, policies, or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
The framework requires the publication of notice of intent in advance of public consultation processes.
The framework requires the publication of proposed regulations.
The framework requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The framework requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
The framework requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
The framework requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
Malta's Freedom of Information (FOI) Act deals with the guidance for collecting and publishing data on the performace on Malta's FOI processes. The FOI Act charges the relevant commissioner with submitting an annual report to the relevant minister who in turn should table it in the Maltese parliament at the first available opportunity. The FOI Act demands that the report in question should state the number of FOI requests made, how many of them were accepted or rejected, the reasons for rejection, the average time taken to reply to requests, the number of complaints received (and other related information), the number of appeals lodged with the relevant tribunal, the number of various notices issued by the commissioner (1). Although the law stipulates an annual report detailing FOI requests, rejections, and otherwise, the last available report is dated 2018 and it does not include all the information required (2).
1)	Freedom of Information Act, Cap. 496, Art. 21. https://legislation.mt/eli/cap/496/eng/pdf
2)	Information and Data Protection Commissioner, 2018, Annual Report 2018. https://parlament.mt/media/105028/04560.pdf.

evidence.title: Data protection chief: Freedom of Information law 'needs to be revised'

indicators.justification: Although legal/consultancy firms appear to offer services that would produce the end result desired by this indicator, no online services/tools that function in the way envisioned by this indicator were found in the case of Malta.

responses.response_text: One or more products/services exist, but they do not appear to make use of open datasets.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of this data being used in products/services?
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, government.

There is evidence of these products/services being promoted to, or used by, the private sector.
There is evidence of these products and services being promoted to, or used by, media.

indicators.justification: No specific instaces of data usage from the Planning Authority's Geoserver were found to influence policy from an academic, civil society, organisations, journalists, and others . Isolated instances of these institutions or entities speaking out about land use matters have been found, however they draw upon specific sources of information and not necessarily open data on land use. No usage of artificial intelligence or machine learning to make use of such land use data was found.

indicators.justification:
There is little to no evidence of government procurement data being analyzed to improve procurement practice. The only relevant evidence was found in the form of a green public procurement action plan covering the period between 2019 and 2025 (1).
1)	Ministry for the Environment, Sustainable Development, and Climate Change, Green Public Procurement National Action Plan 2019-2025, 2018. https://meae.gov.mt/mt/Public_Consultations/MSDEC/Documents/Green%20Public%20Procurement%20National%20Action%20Plan.pdf

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent is there evidence of this kind of data use?
There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
There are examples of government using data in these ways.
There are examples of civil society using data in these ways.
There is evidence of private sector using data in this way
At least one of the examples cited appears to make use of open procurement data.
At least one of the examples identified makes use of open beneficial ownership data.
At least one of the examples identified describes using artificial Intelligence or machine learning to process data
There is evidence that these uses have had or are having meaningful positive impacts.
